author: CBD
title: ANZ boss Mike Smith does a Linda Evangelista on $3b raising announcement
text:
ANZ boss Mike Smith was nowhere to be seen this morning when the bank announced a $3 billion raising. Photo: Arsineh Houspian
Bank watchers were reading a lot in the tea leaves at ANZ when chief teller, Mike Smith, did not show up for the announcement that it was passing the hat around to raise $3 billion .
That was left to his finance chief, Shayne Elliott.
One observer noted that when bank executives raise their capital, and lift provisions for bad debts (as ANZ also did), it can be a signal of a future change in the top executive ranks.
Linda Evangelista won't get out of bed for just anything. Photo: Getty Images
Either that, or, Smith was just doing a Linda "I don't get out of bed for less than $10,000 a day" Evangelista and not getting out of bed for a measly $3 billion raising.
Advertisement ANZ's peeps calmed things down with the information that Smith was busy with the annual board strategy meeting which tied him up on Wednesday and most of Thursday.
And, as promised, Smith was making media calls by lunchtime.
No word on the board deliberations, but it should have been interesting, given all the speculation about Smith's future.
Hopefully the David Gonski-led board have been reading up on the fodder from ANZ's media arm BlueNotes which recently featured a story: How to succeed with CEO succession .
"The key though is having the chairman and the board and the incumbent CEO working hand in glove on the development and execution of the internal succession plan," said the article.
ANZ has been vague about when Smith might be leaving the bank, but some reckon it could happen this year.
Smith got a few giggles from a business crowd in April when he played down talk of his retirement by assuring everyone: "I can assure you there are no slippers waiting in my office.
"To misQuote: Mark Twain, reports of my retirement have been greatly exaggerated," he said.
Succession planning is being discussed "as a matter of course . . . there is no panic".
